#3- up on your toe- push the ball of your toe into the ground- like in an imaginary high heel.

Every time a see a one-legged posture in the video preview, I get a little frustrated. Balancing on one leg is really not my strong suit as my ankles tend to dance around when I do them. I used to get foot cramps when standing on one leg, I got super angry and was avoiding the balancing work.
But magically, Adriene persuaded me to accept where I am and work there. Today, after a couple of years, I don't get cramps in the feet, I can stand on one leg (there's still some wiggling, haha), I am noticing the difference between right and left, differences between days (somedays I still fall, oh yes). I try to laugh off the falls, begin again, enjoy the process.
In the end, it's working on our weaknesses that brings the biggest change. Seeing you CAN evolve, seeing it's not "just who you are". A beautiful lesson to take off the mat as well, don't you think?
One thing that also really helped me ... My cousin is a ballerina, so I talk to her a lot about balance. She said that it helps her to consider this in balancing the body: "Every part of you is carrying itself. It is not up to your foot (or any other part) on the ground to bear all the weight." It helped me a lot, together with engaging my core, learning the bandhas, working on leg strength to manage the slightly bent knee (it's still hard work, man!), but especially working on my MIND.
So, whatever you struggle with, it's ok. Lean in, discover, make space and leave judgment off the mat. Namaste, my friends. Can you believe it's DAY 9 already???
